user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of send_all:
```c
static void
send_all (MHD_socket sock,
          const char *buf,
          size_t len)
{
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t off;

  make_blocking (sock);
  for (off = 0; off < len; off += (size_t) ret)
  {
    ret = send (sock,
                &buf[off],
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
                len - off,
#else  /* Native W32 */
                (int) (len - off),
#endif /* Native W32 */
                0);
    if (0 > ret)
    {
      if (EAGAIN == errno)
      {
        ret = 0;
        continue;
      }
      break;
    }
    if (0 == ret)
      break;
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. Specifically:
- There are no compiler-specific keywords or attributes (for example: __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, typeof, __builtin_*, or other vendor extensions).
- The conditional preprocessor use of _WIN32 and __CYGWIN__ relies on implementation-provided macros to select platform-appropriate code; these are not language extensions themselves but standard practice for portability.
- All casts and types used (size_t, ssize_t, int) are standard C or common platform typedefs provided by system headers; nothing in the snippet invokes a compiler-specific language extension as described in compiler documentation.
- No inline assembly, nonstandard storage-class specifiers, or other documented compiler extensions are present.

Therefore there are no fragments that require further investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 1.2.
